metadata.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Isthmian Steamship Lines

facts.text: The respondent, Messrs. Isthmian Steamship Lines, is a company incorporated in the United States of America and owns steamships which visit India.
The company's Indian profits, computed on the basis of day on round voyage, are assessed to tax under the Indian Income-tax Act as a company through its agents, Messrs. Angus Co., Ltd.

In the course of the assessment for the years 1941-42, 1942-43 and 1943-44, the company claimed that its unabsorbed depreciation at the end of 1938-39 should be deemed to be a part of the depreciation allowance for 1939-40 and therefore such unabsorbed depreciation should be allowed to be further carried forward under Section 10(2)(vi) of the Income-tax Act.
This claim was negatived by the Income-tax Officer, the Appellate Assistant Commissioner of Income-tax and the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal.

The Tribunal, at the instance of the company, referred the following question to the High Court: 'Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of this case the Tribunal was right in holding that the unabsorbed depreciation at the end of the year 1938-39, which was not given effect to in the subsequent years, could be treated as part of the allowable depreciation for the relevant assessment years which are assessment years 1941-42, 1942-43 and 1943-44.'
The High Court answered the question in favour of the company.
The High Court gave a certificate to the Commissioner of Income-tax under Section 66A(2) of the Act to appeal to this Court.
This is an appeal from a judgment of the High Court at Calcutta in a reference under Section 66(1) of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922.
In the assessment for 1940-41, the Income-tax Officer decided that unabsorbed depreciation from end of 1938-39 could not be carried forward, and the company did not appeal against that order.
The assessee's accounting year for assessment year 1938-39 was the calendar year 1937.
The amendment to Section 10(2)(vi) was to take effect from 1st April, 1940.

legal_issues.text: Whether the unabsorbed depreciation at the end of the year 1938-39, which was not given effect to in the subsequent years, could be treated as part of the allowable depreciation for the relevant assessment years 1941-42, 1942-43 and 1943-44.
Whether the company can be allowed to carry forward the unabsorbed depreciation remaining at the end of 1938-39 and treat it as part of the depreciation for 1939-40 and subsequently.

petitioner_arguments.text: By reason of the amendment of the section, the respondent-company was not entitled to carry forward the unabsorbed depreciation at the end of 1938-39.
In the course of the assessment for 1940-41, the question was considered and disallowed by ITO, and no appeal was filed, so matter could not be reopened.
Full effect could not be given to the unabsorbed depreciation not for reasons in the section but due to failure to appeal against 1940-41 assessment.

respondent_arguments.text: Unabsorbed depreciation at the end of 1938-39 should be deemed to be a part of the depreciation allowance for 1939-40 and allowed to be carried forward under Section 10(2)(vi).

court_reasoning.text: The material changes in the amended section are: (1) depreciation based on written down value except for ocean-going steamers; (2) unabsorbed depreciation at end of year prior to 1st April 1939 shall not be carried forward.
Dates apply to assessment year; old law applied up to 1939-40; amendment from 1940-41.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Unabsorbed depreciation from 1938-39 carried to 1939-40 under old law.

court_reasoning.text: Assessment year 1939-40 ended 31st March 1940, not prior to 1st April 1939, so not excluded; can be carried forward to 1940-41 if not absorbed due to insufficient profits.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Proviso condition satisfied as profits less than allowance.

court_reasoning.text: Section says 'where full effect cannot be given' not 'has not been given'; requirements satisfied despite no appeal.
First ground of AAC (no appeal in 1940-41) not pressed as Tribunal rejected it and not referred.

holdings.text: The High Court rightly answered the question in favour of the assessee; company entitled to carry forward unabsorbed depreciation from end of 1938-39 via 1939-40 to subsequent years.
Unabsorbed depreciation for 1939-40 (including carry forward from 1938-39) can be carried to 1940-41 and succeeding years under amended proviso as 1939-40 not a year ended prior to 1st April 1939.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income-tax Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs carry forward of unabsorbed depreciation; amendment in 1939 restricts carry forward from years ending prior to 1st April 1939 but allows from 1939-40 onwards if conditions met.

outcome.summary: The Supreme Court upheld the High Court's answer in favour of the assessee, holding that the company is entitled to carry forward the unabsorbed depreciation from the end of 1938-39 through 1939-40 to the assessment years 1941-42, 1942-43 and 1943-44, as the conditions of Section 10(2)(vi) proviso are satisfied.
outcome.relief_granted: Company's claim for carry forward of unabsorbed depreciation allowed.

key_quotes.text: "where full effect cannot be given to any such allowance in any year, not being a year which ended prior to the 1st day of April, 1939, owing to there being no profits or gains chargeable for the year"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key proviso text interpreted to allow carry forward from 1939-40.

key_quotes.text: The words used in the section are - where full effect cannot be given, and not where full effect has not been given.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Distinguishes reason for non-absorption from procedural failure to appeal.

key_quotes.text: In our opinion, this question has been rightly answered by the High Court in favour of the assessee.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Confirms ruling in favor of respondent.
